wikipedia_page.main: Florence Jessie Collinson MacWilliams (4 January 1917 – 27 May 1990) was an English mathematician who contributed to the field of coding theory, and was one of the first women to publish in the field. MacWilliams' thesis "Combinatorial Problems of Elementary Group Theory" (or "Combinatorial Problems of Elementary Abelian Groups") contains one of the most important combinatorial results in coding theory, and is now known as the MacWilliams Identity.

response: | || Jessie MacWilliams || Developed the MacWilliams identities in coding theory.
The identity is named after Jessie MacWilliams.

Gleason is the namesake of the Gleason polynomials, a system of polynomials that generate the weight enumerators of linear codes.. These polynomials take a particularly simple form for self-dual codes: in this case there are just two of them, the two bivariate polynomials x2 + y2 and x8 + 14x2y2 + y8. Gleason's student Jessie MacWilliams continued Gleason's work in this area, proving a relationship between the weight enumerators of codes and their duals that has become known as the MacWilliams identity.
* Jessie MacWilliams (1917–1990), English researcher on error-correcting codes

Introduction to the Theory of Error-Correcting Codes
response: Other books in this area include The Theory of Error-Correcting Codes (1977) by Jessie MacWilliams and Neil Sloane, and A First Course in Coding Theory (1988) by Raymond Hill.
